metadata.Description: Well organized and easy to understand Web building tutorials with lots of examples of how to use HTML, CSS, JavaScript, SQL, Python, PHP, Bootstrap, Java, XML and more.
metadata.og:description: W3Schools offers free online tutorials, references and exercises in all the major languages of the web. Covering popular subjects like HTML, CSS, JavaScript, Python, SQL, Java, and many, many more.
metadata.keywords: HTML, Python, CSS, SQL, JavaScript, How to, PHP, Java, C, C++, C#, jQuery, Bootstrap, Colors, W3.CSS, XML, MySQL, Icons, NodeJS, React, Graphics, Angular, R, AI, Git, Data Science, Code Game, Tutorials, Programming, Web Development, Training, Learning, Quiz, Exercises, Courses, Lessons, References, Examples, Learn to code, Source code, Demos, Tips, Website

content.text: JavaScript Map Methods
The new Map() Method
You can create a map by passing an array to the new Map() constructor:
content.html: You can create a map by passing an array to the new Map() constructor:

content.code_html:
// Create a Map
 const fruits = new Map([
  ["apples", 500],
  ["bananas", 300],
  ["oranges", 200]
]);

content.text: Map.get()
You get the value of a key in a map with the get() method
content.html: You get the value of a key in a map with the get() method

content.code_html: fruits.get("apples");

content.text: Map.set()
You can add elements to a map with the set() method:
content.html: You can add elements to a map with the set() method:

content.code_html:
// Create a Map
 const fruits = new Map();

// Set Map Values
 fruits.set("apples", 500);
fruits.set("bananas", 300);
fruits.set("oranges", 200);

content.text: The set() method can also be used to change existing map values:
content.html: The set() method can also be used to change existing map values:

content.code_html: fruits.set("apples", 500);

content.text: Map.size
The size property returns the number of elements in a map:
content.html: The size property returns the number of elements in a map:

content.code_html: fruits.size;

content.text: Map.delete()
The delete() method removes a map element:
content.html: The delete() method removes a map element:

content.code_html: fruits.delete("apples");

content.text: Map.clear()
The clear() method removes all the elements from a map:
content.html: The clear() method removes all the elements from a map:

content.code_html: fruits.clear();

content.text: Map.has()
The has() method returns true if a key exists in a map:
content.html: The has() method returns true if a key exists in a map:

content.code_html: fruits.has("apples");

content.text: Map.forEach()
The forEach() method invokes a callback for each key/value pair in a map:
content.html: The forEach() method invokes a callback for each key/value pair in a map:

content.code_html:
// List all entries
 let text = "";
fruits.forEach (function(value, key) {
  text += key + ' = ' + value;
})

content.text: Map.entries()
The entries() method returns an iterator object with the [key,values] in a map:
content.html: The entries() method returns an iterator object with the [key,values] in a map:

content.code_html:
// List all entries
 let text = "";
for (const x of fruits.entries()) {
  text += x;
}

content.text: Map.keys()
The keys() method returns an iterator object with the keys in a map:
content.html: The keys() method returns an iterator object with the keys in a map:

content.code_html:
// List all keys
 let text = "";
for (const x of fruits.keys()) {
  text += x;
}

content.text: Map.values()
The values() method returns an iterator object with the values in a map:
content.html: The values() method returns an iterator object with the values in a map:

content.code_html:
// List all values
 let text = "";
for (const x of fruits.values()) {
  text += x;
}

content.text: You can use the values() method to sum the values in a map:
content.html: You can use the values() method to sum the values in a map:

content.code_html:
// Sum all values
 let total = 0;
for (const x of fruits.values()) {
  total += x;
}

content.text: Objects as Keys
Being able to use objects as keys is an important Map feature.
content.html: Being able to use objects as keys is an important Map feature.

syntaxHighlighting.text: // Add new Elements to the Map

syntax_highlighting.text: // Add new Elements to the Map

content.code_html:
// Create Objects
 const apples = {name: 'Apples'};
const bananas = {name: 'Bananas'};
const oranges = {name: 'Oranges'};

// Create a Map
 const fruits = new Map();

// Add new Elements to the Map
 fruits.set(apples, 500);
fruits.set(bananas, 300);
fruits.set(oranges, 200);

syntax_highlighting_data.text: // Add new Elements to the Map

content.text: Remember: The key is an object (apples), not a string ("apples"):
content.html: Remember: The key is an object (apples), not a string ("apples"):

content.code_html: fruits.get("apples");  // Returns undefined

content.text: JavaScript Map.groupBy()
ES2024 added the Map.groupBy() method to JavaScript.
content.html: ES2024 added the Map.groupBy() method to JavaScript.

content.text: The Map.groupBy() method groups elements of an object according to string values returned from a callback function.
content.html: The Map.groupBy() method groups elements of an object according to string values returned from a callback function.

content.text: The Map.groupBy() method does not change the original object.
content.html: The Map.groupBy() method does not change the original object.

content.code_html:
// Create an Array
 const fruits = [
  {name:"apples", quantity:300},
  {name:"bananas", quantity:500},
  {name:"oranges", quantity:200},
  {name:"kiwi", quantity:150}
];

// Callback function to Group Elements
 function myCallback({ quantity }) {
  return quantity > 200 ? "ok" : "low";
}

// Group by Quantity
 const result = Map.groupBy(fruits, myCallback);

content.text: Browser Support
Map.groupby() is an ES2024 feature.
content.html: Map.groupby() is an ES2024 feature.

content.text: It is supported in new browsers since March 2024:
content.html: It is supported in new browsers since March 2024:

content.code_html:
Chrome 117 Edge 117 Firefox 119 Safari 17.4 Opera 103
Sep 2023 Sep 2023 Oct 2023 Okt 2024 May 2023

content.text: Warning
ES2024 features are relatively new.
content.html: ES2024 features are relatively new.

content.text: Older browsers may need an alternative code (Polyfill)
content.html: Older browsers may need an alternative code (Polyfill)

content.text: Object.groupBy() vs Map.groupBy()
The difference between Object.groupBy() and Map.groupBy() is:
content.html: The difference between Object.groupBy() and Map.groupBy() is:

content.text: Object.groupBy() groups elements into a JavaScript object.
content.html: Object.groupBy() groups elements into a JavaScript object.

content.text: Map.groupBy() groups elements into a Map object.
content.html: Map.groupBy() groups elements into a Map object.

content.html: For a complete reference, go to our:

content.html: Complete JavaScript Map Reference.

content.text: The reference contains descriptions and examples of all Map Properties and Methods.
content.html: The reference contains descriptions and examples of all Map Properties and Methods.

Which property can be used to return the number of elements in a Map?
content.html: Which property can be used to return the number of elements in a Map?
